issue.title: Importing puslar client libraries creates zombie dbus processes

labels.name: annoying
labels.description: Benthos is mildly annoying but not quite a bug

labels.name: waiting for upstream
labels.description: Blocked on changes needed in an upstream dependency

issue.body:
As per discord chat with @Jeffail and @mihaitodor:

Running any of benthos subcommands in a cronjob will create
`/usr/bin/dbus-daemon --session` processes for every invocation, slowing down
the system or ultimately crashing it.

This is most likely because there are no dbus sessions available to cron processes.

Way to reproduce:

```
# cat /etc/cron.d/foo
* * * * * root benthos --version
# Wait a few minutes
# ps aux | grep dbus
message+     605  0.0  0.0   8572  4460 ?        Ss   11:28   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --system --address=systemd: --nofork --nopidfile --systemd-activation --syslog-o
root      302826  0.0  0.0   8268  2480 ?        Ss   19:16   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      303318  0.0  0.0   8268  2480 ?        Ss   19:17   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      303870  0.0  0.0   8268  2504 ?        Ss   19:18   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
... a few more ...
root      309243  0.0  0.0   8268  2480 ?        Ss   19:28   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      309737  0.0  0.0   8268  2540 ?        Ss   19:29   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      310353  0.0  0.0   8268  2484 ?        Ss   19:30   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      310842  0.0  0.0   8268  2484 ?        Ss   19:31   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
```

This also happens on every invocation in a regular shell on a system where dbus
is disabled / not existent (e.g. OpenRC systems).

The root cause is most likely this:
https://github.com/99designs/keyring/blob/81fed19d324843057dab56ba67dd0db54d1d4626/secretservice.go#L19

Workaround is to set `DBUS_SESSION_BUS_ADDRESS=/dev/null` as environment
variable in the cron file or from where ever else you might run it.

comment.body:
For now, if you wish to use the Pulsar components, you should import Benthos as a library as explained [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/migration/v4#pulsar-components-disabled-for-now) and build it using Go 1.18+. The steps would be the following:

- Download & install Go 1.18 (or use the official Docker container)
- Create a folder somewhere and place in it `main.go` with the contents that I linked above
- Run in that folder `go build -o benthos .`
- You should now have a fully-featured `benthos` binary including Pulsar support

issue.title: Output subprocess dynamic
issue.body:
Hello all,
I try to use subprocess output but i don't know if it's the best way for implement my use case.

My config.yml

```
input:
  label: ""
  kafka:
    addresses: ["ip:29092"]
    topics: ["topic"]
    target_version: 2.0.0
    consumer_group: "group_name"
    checkpoint_limit: 1024
    
- mapping: |
        root.param1 = this.id

output:
  broker:
    outputs:
    - subprocess:
        name: "node"
        args: ["run"]
        codec: lines
```

I want to run dynamic command like 

`node run {"param1": "value1"}`

where the value of the hash key "param1" is the result of a mapping processor 'root.param1'

comment.body:
Hey @malveslobo, the `subprocess` output doesn't work this way, as it's meant to start a long-running process which keeps reading data from stdin. See the docs [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/subprocess). If you're using node anyway, the easiest and more reliable thing to do might be to add a small HTTP server into your node app and then use the `http_client` output in Benthos. Having said that, you can try a quick and dirty workaround using bash:

```shell
#!/bin/bash

while read -r line
do
    node run "${line}"
done
```

Put this script in a file, do `subprocess.name: wrapper.sh` and leave the `args` empty (unless you also want to make it more complex and pass some args to it).

issue.title: Add service.AutoRetryNacks test for read after close
issue.body:
I believe this test should succeed, but I could be wrong... 

I'm trying to fix this other test https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/main/internal/impl/mongodb/input_test.go and it looks like there's smth wonky with the way `public/service/input_auto_retry.go` works. Basically, I'm expecting `selectInput.Read(ctx)` here https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/b195d9eb87f6b4a5637330f4e276b06ea344ff17/internal/impl/mongodb/input_test.go#L235 to unblock when `service.ErrEndOfInput` is returned by the input `Read()` method, but that doesn't seem to be the case. Right now, it's just blocking forever, because the test author of the test didn't use `context.WithTimeout()`, but that's another issue... There are a few other issues in this MongoDB test that I'll address once this issue is clarified.

comment.body: OK, it should be good to go now. I think it's a useful test to have there in case I need to review this logic again in the future.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -339,3 +339,51 @@ func TestAutoRetryBuffer(t *testing.T) {
 	require.NoError(t, err)
 	assert.Equal(t, exp3, string(b))
 }
+
+func TestAutoRetryReadAfterClose(t *testing.T) {
+	t.Parallel()
+
+	ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), time.Second*2)
+	defer cancel()
+
+	readerImpl := newMockInput()
+	readerImpl.msgsToSnd = append(readerImpl.msgsToSnd, NewMessage([]byte("foo")))
+
+	pres := AutoRetryNacks(readerImpl)
+
+	wg := sync.WaitGroup{}
+	wg.Add(1)
+	go func() {
+		defer wg.Done()
+		select {
+		case readerImpl.connChan <- nil:
+		case <-time.After(time.Second):
+			t.Error("Timed out")
+		}
+		select {
+		case readerImpl.readChan <- nil:
+		case <-time.After(time.Second):
+			t.Error("Timed out")
+		}
+
+		// Force mockInput.Read() to return ErrEndOfInput
+		close(readerImpl.readChan)
+	}()
+
+	require.NoError(t, pres.Connect(ctx))
+
+	msg, _, err := pres.Read(ctx)
comment.body: Ahhhhh! That makes sense. I forgot about the ack function... Indeed, it has to be called to unblock the workflow. Thanks a million! 😘

issue.title: Implement `event_window` buffer

labels.name: buffers
labels.description: Any tasks or issues relating specifically to buffers

issue.body:
Input data (./data/dump.txt):
```
{"created_at":"2022-11-21T08:26:47.872179604Z","event_type_id":"17"}
{"created_at":"2022-11-21T08:26:56.513210883Z","event_type_id":"26"}
```

Config (benthos.yaml):

```
input:
  label: ""
  file:
    paths: [ ./data/dump.txt ]
    codec: lines

buffer:
  system_window:
    timestamp_mapping: root = this.created_at
#    timestamp_mapping: root = now()
    size: 1s
    allowed_lateness: 10ms

pipeline:
  processors:
  - group_by_value:
      value: ${! meta("window_end_timestamp") }
  - mapping: |
      root = if batch_index() == 0 {
        {
          "events_count": json("created_at").from_all().length(),
          "window_closed_at": meta("window_end_timestamp"),
          "first_event_time": this.created_at,
        }
      } else { deleted() }

output:
  label: "output"
  stdout:
    codec: lines

logger:
  level: ALL
  format: logfmt
  add_timestamp: false
  static_fields: { }
```

Exec:
```
	docker run \
		--rm \
		-p 4195:4195 \
		-v $(shell pwd)/benthos.yaml:/benthos.yaml \
		-v $(shell pwd)/data:/data \
		jeffail/benthos:4.10.0 \
		-c /benthos.yaml
```

We have no closed windows (two closed windows expected). Is this a bug?

Log:
```
level=info msg="Running main config from specified file" path=/benthos.yaml
level=info msg="Consuming from file './data/dump.txt'" label="" path=root.input
level=trace msg="Consumed 1 messages from 'file'." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Launching a benthos instance, use CTRL+C to close"
level=trace msg="Consumed 1 messages from 'file'." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Listening for HTTP requests at: http://0.0.0.0:4195"
level=debug msg="Waiting for pending acks to resolve before shutting down." label="" path=root.input
level=debug msg="Pending acks resolved." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Pipeline has terminated. Shutting down the service"

Process finished with exit code 0
```

But if replace `timestamp_mapping` to `root = now()` - one closed window (as expected).

Log:
```
level=info msg="Running main config from specified file" path=/benthos.yaml
level=info msg="Consuming from file './data/dump.txt'" label="" path=root.input
level=trace msg="Consumed 1 messages from 'file'." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Launching a benthos instance, use CTRL+C to close"
level=trace msg="Consumed 1 messages from 'file'." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Listening for HTTP requests at: http://0.0.0.0:4195"
level=trace msg="New group formed: 2022-11-21T09:56:21Z" label="" path=root.pipeline.processors.0
level=trace msg="Attempting to write 1 messages to 'stdout'." label=output path=root.output
level=trace msg="Successfully wrote 1 messages to 'stdout'." label=output path=root.output
level=debug msg="Waiting for pending acks to resolve before shutting down." label="" path=root.input
level=debug msg="Pending acks resolved." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Pipeline has terminated. Shutting down the service"
{"events_count":2,"first_event_time":"2022-11-21T08:26:47.872179604Z","window_closed_at":"2022-11-21T09:56:21Z"}

Process finished with exit code 0
```

comment.body: @rolandtritsch I don't really know what people might expect from a generic `event_window` buffer and I'd rather defer to Ash for a potential implementation that is worth pushing into the Benthos codebase, but I could try to help you implement what you're looking to have as a custom plugin, similar to the example here: https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/benthosdev/benthos/v4@v4.10.0/public/service#example-package-BufferPlugin Guess some of the logic from the [`system_window` buffer](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/3f055f41f6494f1feeaec435614f36a8e4375652/internal/impl/pure/buffer_system_window.go) can be reused. We can chat about it on Discord if you'd like. Feel free to DM me.

issue.title: Reading a avro file and decode the go native types
issue.body: @karrick can you please help me with any links or example where they are reading from avro file and then parsing it to Go native types, using either codec.NativeFromTextual or codec.NativeFromBinary APIs. Im struggling a bit for this.

comment.body: Both `NativeFromTextual` and `NativeFromBinary` produce a "native" object that I think is only meant to be used by the Goavro APIs. What you can do is to then call `TextualFromNative` to obtain a JSON string representation and then use `json.Unmarshal` to decode that into a Go structure. Alternatively, I can imagine using something like [mapstructure](https://github.com/mitchellh/mapstructure) to extract what you need from the "native" object, but I'm not sure if that's such a good idea...

issue.title: Sort Output
issue.body:
Hello, 

I have a CSV file.

I try to process each line to add a new field, then, i want to output the line sorted in a new csv file. 
I don't understand how can i sort my output 

For example, with this input csv: 

```csv
first_name;last_name
Bruce;Banner
Tony;Stark
Bruce;Wayne
Barry;Allen
Jason;Todd
Dick;Grayson
```
I want to output this csv : 

```csv
first_name;last_name;full_name
Barry;Allen;Bruce Wayne
Bruce;Banner;Dick Grayson
Bruce;Wayne;Barry Allen
Dick;Grayson;Bruce Banner
Jason;Todd;Tony Stark
Tony;Stark;Jason Todd
```

Currently, i have this config

```yaml
input:
  csv:
    paths: [./benthos.csv]
    delimiter: ";"
    parse_header_row: true

pipeline:
  processors:
    - bloblang: |
        root = this
        root.full_name = this.first_name + " " + this.last_name      
        
output:
  file:
    path: ./benthos_output.csv
```    

But don't understand how i can sort the full batch of line, and not something inside each line

comment.body:
Hey @Varkal, Benthos is a data streaming processor, meaning that it's not really intended for use cases where the entire input data needs to end up in a certain order. Having said that, there are workarounds with various caveats, such as this one:

```yaml
input:
  csv:
    paths: [./benthos.csv]
    delimiter: ";"
    parse_header_row: true

buffer:
  memory:
    limit: 1048576 # 100MB - Something larger than the total size of your input data
    batch_policy:
      enabled: true
      count: 1000000 # 1 million - Something larger than the total number of rows you can possibly have in your input

pipeline:
  processors:
    - archive:
        format: json_array
    - mapping: |
        map escape_csv {
          root = if this.re_match("[\"\n,]+") {
            "\"" + this.replace_all("\"", "\"\"") + "\""
          } else {
            this
          }
        }

        let rows = this.sort_by(i -> i.first_name).map_each(i -> i.merge({"full_name": i.first_name + " " + i.last_name}))
        let cols = $rows.index(0).keys().sort() # Sort here to ensure the order of the columns in the output is deterministic
        let header = $cols.map_each(kv -> kv.apply("escape_csv")).join(",") + "\n"

        root = $header + $rows.map_each(row -> $cols.map_each(c -> row.get(c).string().apply("escape_csv")).join(",")).join("\n")

output:
  file:
    path: ./benthos_output.csv
```

Caveats:
- We must force Benthos to read all the input data in memory. Since you need a custom delimiter, we can't just use the `file` input with `codec: all-bytes` because the [`unarchive` processor](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/unarchive) doesn't support custom delimiters when specifying `format: csv` and the [`parse_csv` bloblang method](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/methods#parse_csv) has the same limitation right now, but I'll send a PR soon to extend the latter. Until then, using a large enough in-memory buffer will do the trick. Alternatively, parsing the CSV manually using various string functions in bloblang is possible, but I'd rather not go down that route... If needed, you could write your own [custom plugin](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos-plugin-example).
- The in-memory buffer batches all the rows (messages) into a batch which we need to collapse into a single message using the `archive` processor, so we can then use the [`sort_by` bloblang method](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/methods#sort_by).
- Since JSON objects don't have any column order, then we must manually sort the columns too if we want the final output CSV to be deterministic. Currently, the `csv` input doesn't store the original column order anywhere, so that information is lost. If it's mandatory to preserve the column order from the input, I have that code almost ready.
- There's no `format_csv` bloblang method / processor or `csv` output yet because it's a bit unclear how to make it generic, but, as explained [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/advanced#creating-csv) there are some workarounds. The mapping I created above is one way, but definitely not the most efficient possible.

Having said that, there are other tools out there which might be more suitable for achieving your goal, such as [xsv](https://github.com/BurntSushi/xsv), [miller](https://github.com/johnkerl/miller), [q](http://github.com/harelba/q), etc.

issue.title: Redaction via struct tags
issue.body:
Would you consider enabling redaction via struct tags? Ideally, I'd like to use it in combination with https://github.com/caarlos0/env like so:
```go
type Config struct {
	Username string `env:"USERNAME" envDefault:"mihai"`
	Password  string `env:"PASSWORD,required" rubberneck:"redact"`
}
```
Maybe the `rubberneck:"redact"` can be even more versatile, to allow users to specify the redaction symbol for example.

For prior art, I found https://github.com/leebenson/conform and I can get it to do redaction through a one liner like so:
```go
conform.AddSanitizer("redact", func(s string) string { return strings.Repeat("*", len(s)) })
```

But it would be so much nicer to have an all-in-one solution :)

comment.body: Cool, I'll see if I can send a PR, but it might have to wait a bit :)

issue.body:
It would be great to have a support for fetching emails and sending them to different outputs like MongoDB, Redis, RabbitMQ and so on.

And the opposite, being able to send email from different inputs.

Currently the alternative is to use a middleman like sendgrid for receiving email over HTTP webhook or sending email through the HTTP rest API.

My use case is to create GitHub issues when receiving an email and also send an email when a reply is sent on an issue.

issue.body:
# Summary of Changes

This adds the required config for VS Code [Dev Container](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/devcontainers/containers) support. With this change, opening the repo in VS Code will prompt you to reload the editor and, assuming you have Docker up and running, it will pull the required Docker image and start it. Expect it to download a 1.4GB image. Once the container is running, it will install a bunch of dependencies, including `tox`. It will show you the log as it progresses, but, at the end of the process, VS Code will run in this container in headless mode and you can open a separate terminal in which you can run the `tox` command which should complete successfully.

I haven't spotted any specific section related to the code editor in the Readme / Contributing docs, so not sure if you'd like to have a paragraph about this feature, or at least mention somewhere that people will want to use VS Code if they wish to leverage this Dev Container setup for their work / tests.

# Related Issues

Fixes #1979.

# Pull Request Checklist

This is just a reminder about the most common mistakes.  Please make sure that you tick all *appropriate* boxes.  But please read our [contribution guide](../CONTRIBUTING.md) at least once; it will save you a few review cycles!

If an item doesn't apply to your pull request, **check it anyway** to make it apparent that there's nothing to do.

issue.body: I'd like to suggest adding support for Salesforce Object Query Language (SOQL)  as an input/output. I'm willing to take a stab at implementing this if I get the spare time to do it.

comment.body:
No, it doesn't require a sequence input and you can leverage the `memory` cache `default_ttl` to expire tokens. Here's how I'd do it:

```yaml
input:
  generate:
    interval: 10s # Trigger the pipeline every 10s
    mapping: root = ""
    count: 0 # Never stop

  processors:
    - cache: # Try to fetch the auth token from the cache
        resource: token_cache
        operator: get
        key: token
    - catch:
        - http: {} # Fetch the auth token from the API
        - catch:
            - log:
                level: WARN
                message: "Failed to get token: ${! error() }"
            - bloblang: root = deleted() # Prevent the rest of the pipeline from running
        - mapping: |
            meta token = ... # Do some processing to extract the actual token and place it in
        - branch:
            request_map: |
              root = meta("token")
            processors:
              - cache: # Cache the current auth token
                  resource: token_cache
                  operator: set
                  key: token
                  value: "${! content() }"
    - http: {} # Fetch some data using meta("token")

output:
  stdout: {}

cache_resources:
  - label: token_cache
    memory:
      ttl: 1h # Expire auth tokens after 1h
```

Note that the above is just a sketch config and it might have bugs...

issue.title: OUTPUT - Multi SQL insert from args_mapping

labels.name: needs investigation
labels.description: It looks as though have all the information needed but investigation is required

issue.body:
Right now the [SQL insert](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/sql_insert) output only supports 1 item. I would like to have an option that will accept an array of items from the `args_mapping` that can than be expanded in the following manner.

```sql
INSERT INTO table(a, b, c) VALUES (j, k, l), (x, y, z);
```

This way it will be done in 1 statement instead of multiple INSERTS.

comment.body:
Sure! I guess you can start with something like this:

```yaml
input:
  generate:
    mapping: |
      root.type = if count("type") % 3 == 1 { "order" } else { "item" }
      root.id = uuid_v4()
    count: 9
    interval: 0s
    batch_size: 3
  processors:
    - archive:
        format: json_array
    - mapping: |
        root.order = this.filter(item -> item.type == "order").index(0)
        root.items = this.filter(item -> item.type == "item")

output:
  sql_raw:
    driver: sqlite
    dsn: file:./foobar.db
    query: |
      BEGIN TRANSACTION;
      INSERT INTO orders (id) VALUES (?);
      INSERT INTO order_items (id, order_id) VALUES ${! json("items").map_each(i -> "(?, ?)").join(",") };
      COMMIT;
    unsafe_dynamic_query: true
    args_mapping: |
      root = [ this.order.id ].append(this.items.map_each(i -> [this.order.id, i.id]).flatten()).flatten()
    conn_max_idle: 1
    conn_max_open: 1
    init_statement: |
      CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS orders (
        id varchar
      );
      CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS order_items (
        id varchar,
        order_id varchar
      );
```

I'm making some possibly undesired assumptions in there:
- Each batch contains exactly one order and multiple items which have to be inserted in one single transaction
- An order is inserted together with its items in a single transaction
- There's just a single column in each of the two tables called `id`, but you can change that by adjusting the `query` and `args_mapping` fields

> How should a package be emitting logs in a way that makes it ok to use in Benthos?

Have a look at any of the existing implementations under `internal/impl`. For example [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/b0f68e94d7e4e42a7a929b1e493f0fe3e6d84c88/internal/impl/snowflake/output_snowflake_put.go#L734). You can see how that `logger` object is hooked up.

> Someone submitted an issue last year to add an option to disable logging in that package: [https://github.com/https://github.com/simpleforce/simpleforce/issues/35]

Yeah, the package doesn't seem to be great or well-maintained. It also doesn't contain that much code, so I really wonder if it's really useful to import it. It might be better to leverage the Benthos `http_client` directly and write templates, similar to how the Discord input is [implemented](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/main/template/inputs/discord.yaml)

issue.title: how to Preserving key order by json parse  ?

comment.body:
Key order is undefined in JSON and, because Go uses maps to hold JSON objects, the order will not be preserved. Details here: https://github.com/golang/go/issues/27179. When marshalling to string, the keys will be [sorted lexicographically](https://pkg.go.dev/encoding/json):

> Map values encode as JSON objects. The map's key type must either be a string, an integer type, or implement encoding.TextMarshaler. The map keys are sorted and used as JSON object keys by applying the following rules, subject to the UTF-8 coercion described for string values above:
> 
>     keys of any string type are used directly
>     encoding.TextMarshalers are marshaled
>     integer keys are converted to strings

issue.title: base64_decode execution error
issue.body:
There is an error using base64_decode in awk processor.
the error info is:
```
level=error msg="Non-fatal execution error: illegal base64 data at input byte 43220" @service=benthos label="" path=root.pipeline.processors.2
```
my benthos.config:
```yaml
input:
  broker:
    inputs:
      - kafka:
          addresses: kafka_addrss
          topics: kafka_topic
          consumer_group: kafka_group
          sasl:
            mechanism: kafka_me
            user: kafka_user
            password: kafka_password
pipeline:
  processors:
    - protobuf:
        operator: to_json
        message: subscribe.Envelope
        import_paths: [ subscribe/subscribe.proto ]
    - awk:
        codec: "json"
        program: |
          function readfile(file, tmp, save_rs){
            save_rs = RS
            RS = "^$"
            getline tmp < file
            close(file)
            RS = save_rs

            return tmp
          }
          {
            total_value = json_get("total")
            index_type = json_type("index")
            if (index_type == "undefined") {
              json_set_int("index",0)
            }
            index_value = json_get("index")
            data_value = json_get("data")
            if (index_value == "0") {
              print data_value > "./result.json"
            } else {
              file_data = readfile("./result.json")
              gsub(/\s/,"",file_data)
              file_data = sprintf("%s%s",file_data,data_value)
              print data_value > "./result.json"
              }
            }
    - awk: 
        codec: "json"
        program: |
          function readfile(file, tmp, save_rs){
            save_rs = RS
            RS = "^$"
            getline tmp < file
            close(file)
            RS = save_rs

            return tmp
          }
          {
            data_com = readfile("./result.json")
            gsub(/\s/,"",data_com)
            decode_data = base64_decode(data_com)
            json_set("data",decode_data)
          }
    - catch: 
        - resource: error_data
    - bloblang: |
        root = this.data
    - protobuf:
        operator: to_json
        message: subscribe.Entries
        import_paths: [subscribe/subscribe.proto]
          
processor_resources:
  - label: error_data
    awk:
      codec: "json"
      program: |
        function readfile(file, tmp, save_rs){
          save_rs = RS
          RS = "^$"
          getline tmp < file
          close(file)
          RS = save_rs
          return tmp
        }
        {
          data_com = readfile("./result.json")
          gsub(/\s/,"",data_com)
          print data_com > "./err_data.json"
        }
output: 
  drop: {}
```
Why does decoding fail? My data is processed from protobuf processor.

comment.body:
> Why does decoding fail? My data is processed from protobuf processor.

I see many operations in there before it even reaches `base64_decode`. It's really hard to tell if, indeed, that `result.json` file contains a valid base64-encoded string. To narrow it down, I suggest you insert a `log` processor between the `protobuf` one and the first `awk` one and then, after you capture one of those messages, replace your input with a `generate` input which simply produces the data from the JSON you captured. That way, you'll have an easily-reproducible example to play with and share with us if you still need help.

Additionally, it seems to me like a lot of the logic which is done via `awk`, if not all of it, would be way more maintainable if expressed via bloblang using `mapping` processors. Have you found some limitations in bloblang which prevent you from using it? Also, storing state to disk in those json files via `awk` makes things way more difficult than they should be. Have you considered using a [cache](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/caches/about) instead? Also, if it's something related to the current message, [metadata](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/configuration/metadata/) is getting [support](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/issues/1558) for structured data in the next release, which can simplify things a lot.

Another thing to keep in mind is that if any of the processors fails, you can inspect the error in a `log` processor using `message: ${! error() }`. The `error()` function is documented [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/functions#error).

issue.body:
Hi,
I have a requirement of validating filename (naming standard, extension etc.) hence I do not need to read the content of the file. But I am able formulate the logic of validation successfully like below.
meta("path").filepath_split().index(1).has_suffix("csv") 
But this logic gets evaluated per file record count. Is it possible it run the processor per file only once.
Reference code snippet below.
input:
  broker:
    inputs:
      - resource: in_files
pipeline:
  threads: 1
  processors:
     - try:
        - resource: resource_1
        - resource: resource_2  
        - log:
             level: INFO
             message: execution start  
     - catch:
       - log:
          level: ERROR
          message: "Failed due to: ${! error() }"
       - resource: resource_3
output:
  switch:
    cases:
      - check: this.status=="ERROR"
        output:
          label: error
          processors:
            - resource: resource_4
          file:
            path: /output/${! "${ERROR_FILE_PREFIX}"}${! timestamp_unix() }.ERROR.LOG
            codec: lines

processor_resources:
        - label: resource_1
          bloblang: |
            root.filename = meta("path").filepath_split().index(1)
            root.status = "COMPLETED"
        - label: resource_2
          bloblang: |
            if (!this.filename.has_suffix("csv")  ){
               throw("File Extention is invalid")
            }
        - label: resource_3
          bloblang: |
              root.status = "ERROR"
              root.filename = meta("path").filepath_split().index(1)
              root.reason = "%s%v".format("Failed due to: ",error())
        - label: resource_4
          bloblang: |
            "FILE : %s\rREASON : %s \r\r".format(this.filename, this.reason)                    

input_resources:
  - label: in_files
    file:
      paths:
        - /input/*.*

comment.body: Hey @dhaldergit, it sounds like you'd want the `file` input to only emit one message for each file read containing only the metadata of the files. I guess we could add something like a `metadata` codec, but it will require a bit of investigation.

pull_request.title: Add format_xml bloblang method
pull_request.body:
Also add `no_indent` parameter to the `format_json()` bloblang method. Unfortunately, we can't currently distinguish between `format_json()` and `format_json("    ")`, so the easiest thing to do is to add an extra parameter to be consistent with `format_xml()`. Otherwise, people can't force these methods to not insert any `\n` characters, because setting the indent to `""` still emits them and, then again, diverging from the Go API behaviour is probably a bad idea...

Unfortunately, I couldn't use `encoding/xml` for this task because it has some limitations such as https://github.com/golang/go/issues/48624. It's not clear to me why it doesn't support the same kinds of inputs as `encoding/json`, but, alas...

issue.title: Would you consider maintaining a devcontainer for VS Code?
issue.body:
I struggled a bit to get `tools/mintest.sh` to run and since I'm not a very experienced Python developer, setting up the prerequisites on OSX proved to be a challenge. Having multiple versions of Python in parallel seems a bit error-prone to me. I guess using `pyenv` from the start is the way to go, but wasn't sure based on the instructions from [here](https://github.com/falconry/falcon/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md). On the other hand, I recently played around with a project called Keda and I found [their devcontainer setup](https://github.com/kedacore/keda/tree/main/.devcontainer) quite easy to use, assuming one is willing to run Docker. Basically, VS Code starts a headless server in the container automatically and then the UI communicates with it seamlessly.

For Falcon, I found it easier to install all the dependencies in a Docker container and run everything there without worrying about messing up Python on my local laptop:
```shell
> docker run --rm -it -v$(pwd):/workspace ubuntu bash
>> apt update && DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive apt install -y software-properties-common ca-certificates curl build-essential python3-distutils python3-pip
>> add-apt-repository -y ppa:deadsnakes/ppa && apt update
>> apt install -y python3.5 python3.8 python3.5-dev python3.8-dev
>> pip install -U pip setuptools tox wheel
>> cd /workspace
>> # Run mintest
>> tools/mintest.sh
>> # Run asgilook test
>> tox --recreate -e asgilook
>> # Run asgilook tests without refreshing dependencies
>> tox --skip-pkg-install -e asgilook
```

I can easily wrap the above in a devcontainer if you'd like.

(Run `towncrier --draft` to ensure it renders correctly.)

If you have *any* questions to *any* of the points above, just **submit and ask**! This checklist is here to *help* you, not to deter you from contributing!

issue.title: Importing puslar client libraries creates zombie dbus processes

labels.name: annoying
labels.description: Benthos is mildly annoying but not quite a bug

labels.name: waiting for upstream
labels.description: Blocked on changes needed in an upstream dependency

issue.body:
As per discord chat with @Jeffail and @mihaitodor:

Running any of benthos subcommands in a cronjob will create
`/usr/bin/dbus-daemon --session` processes for every invocation, slowing down
the system or ultimately crashing it.

This is most likely because there are no dbus sessions available to cron processes.

Way to reproduce:

```
# cat /etc/cron.d/foo
* * * * * root benthos --version
# Wait a few minutes
# ps aux | grep dbus
message+     605  0.0  0.0   8572  4460 ?        Ss   11:28   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --system --address=systemd: --nofork --nopidfile --systemd-activation --syslog-o
root      302826  0.0  0.0   8268  2480 ?        Ss   19:16   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      303318  0.0  0.0   8268  2480 ?        Ss   19:17   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      303870  0.0  0.0   8268  2504 ?        Ss   19:18   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
... a few more ...
root      309243  0.0  0.0   8268  2480 ?        Ss   19:28   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      309737  0.0  0.0   8268  2540 ?        Ss   19:29   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      310353  0.0  0.0   8268  2484 ?        Ss   19:30   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      310842  0.0  0.0   8268  2484 ?        Ss   19:31   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
```

This also happens on every invocation in a regular shell on a system where dbus
is disabled / not existent (e.g. OpenRC systems).

The root cause is most likely this:
https://github.com/99designs/keyring/blob/81fed19d324843057dab56ba67dd0db54d1d4626/secretservice.go#L19

Workaround is to set `DBUS_SESSION_BUS_ADDRESS=/dev/null` as environment
variable in the cron file or from where ever else you might run it.

issue.title: Output subprocess dynamic
issue.body:
Hello all,
I try to use subprocess output but i don't know if it's the best way for implement my use case.

My config.yml

```
input:
  label: ""
  kafka:
    addresses: ["ip:29092"]
    topics: ["topic"]
    target_version: 2.0.0
    consumer_group: "group_name"
    checkpoint_limit: 1024
    
- mapping: |
        root.param1 = this.id

output:
  broker:
    outputs:
    - subprocess:
        name: "node"
        args: ["run"]
        codec: lines
```

I want to run dynamic command like 

`node run {"param1": "value1"}`

where the value of the hash key "param1" is the result of a mapping processor 'root.param1'

comment.body:
Hey @malveslobo, the `subprocess` output doesn't work this way, as it's meant to start a long-running process which keeps reading data from stdin. See the docs [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/subprocess). If you're using node anyway, the easiest and more reliable thing to do might be to add a small HTTP server into your node app and then use the `http_client` output in Benthos. Having said that, you can try a quick and dirty workaround using bash:

```shell
#!/bin/bash

while read -r line
do
    node run "${line}"
done
```

Put this script in a file, do `subprocess.name: wrapper.sh` and leave the `args` empty (unless you also want to make it more complex and pass some args to it).

issue.title: Add service.AutoRetryNacks test for read after close
issue.body:
I believe this test should succeed, but I could be wrong... 

I'm trying to fix this other test https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/main/internal/impl/mongodb/input_test.go and it looks like there's smth wonky with the way `public/service/input_auto_retry.go` works. Basically, I'm expecting `selectInput.Read(ctx)` here https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/b195d9eb87f6b4a5637330f4e276b06ea344ff17/internal/impl/mongodb/input_test.go#L235 to unblock when `service.ErrEndOfInput` is returned by the input `Read()` method, but that doesn't seem to be the case. Right now, it's just blocking forever, because the test author of the test didn't use `context.WithTimeout()`, but that's another issue... There are a few other issues in this MongoDB test that I'll address once this issue is clarified.

comment.body: OK, it should be good to go now. I think it's a useful test to have there in case I need to review this logic again in the future.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -339,3 +339,51 @@ func TestAutoRetryBuffer(t *testing.T) {
 	require.NoError(t, err)
 	assert.Equal(t, exp3, string(b))
 }
+
+func TestAutoRetryReadAfterClose(t *testing.T) {
+	t.Parallel()
+
+	ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), time.Second*2)
+	defer cancel()
+
+	readerImpl := newMockInput()
+	readerImpl.msgsToSnd = append(readerImpl.msgsToSnd, NewMessage([]byte("foo")))
+
+	pres := AutoRetryNacks(readerImpl)
+
+	wg := sync.WaitGroup{}
+	wg.Add(1)
+	go func() {
+		defer wg.Done()
+		select {
+		case readerImpl.connChan <- nil:
+		case <-time.After(time.Second):
+			t.Error("Timed out")
+		}
+		select {
+		case readerImpl.readChan <- nil:
+		case <-time.After(time.Second):
+			t.Error("Timed out")
+		}
+
+		// Force mockInput.Read() to return ErrEndOfInput
+		close(readerImpl.readChan)
+	}()
+
+	require.NoError(t, pres.Connect(ctx))
+
+	msg, _, err := pres.Read(ctx)
comment.body: Ahhhhh! That makes sense. I forgot about the ack function... Indeed, it has to be called to unblock the workflow. Thanks a million! 😘

issue.title: Implement `event_window` buffer

labels.name: buffers
labels.description: Any tasks or issues relating specifically to buffers

issue.body:
Input data (./data/dump.txt):
```
{"created_at":"2022-11-21T08:26:47.872179604Z","event_type_id":"17"}
{"created_at":"2022-11-21T08:26:56.513210883Z","event_type_id":"26"}
```

Config (benthos.yaml):

```
input:
  label: ""
  file:
    paths: [ ./data/dump.txt ]
    codec: lines

buffer:
  system_window:
    timestamp_mapping: root = this.created_at
#    timestamp_mapping: root = now()
    size: 1s
    allowed_lateness: 10ms

pipeline:
  processors:
  - group_by_value:
      value: ${! meta("window_end_timestamp") }
  - mapping: |
      root = if batch_index() == 0 {
        {
          "events_count": json("created_at").from_all().length(),
          "window_closed_at": meta("window_end_timestamp"),
          "first_event_time": this.created_at,
        }
      } else { deleted() }

output:
  label: "output"
  stdout:
    codec: lines

logger:
  level: ALL
  format: logfmt
  add_timestamp: false
  static_fields: { }
```

Exec:
```
	docker run \
		--rm \
		-p 4195:4195 \
		-v $(shell pwd)/benthos.yaml:/benthos.yaml \
		-v $(shell pwd)/data:/data \
		jeffail/benthos:4.10.0 \
		-c /benthos.yaml
```

We have no closed windows (two closed windows expected). Is this a bug?

Log:
```
level=info msg="Running main config from specified file" path=/benthos.yaml
level=info msg="Consuming from file './data/dump.txt'" label="" path=root.input
level=trace msg="Consumed 1 messages from 'file'." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Launching a benthos instance, use CTRL+C to close"
level=trace msg="Consumed 1 messages from 'file'." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Listening for HTTP requests at: http://0.0.0.0:4195"
level=debug msg="Waiting for pending acks to resolve before shutting down." label="" path=root.input
level=debug msg="Pending acks resolved." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Pipeline has terminated. Shutting down the service"

Process finished with exit code 0
```

But if replace `timestamp_mapping` to `root = now()` - one closed window (as expected).

Log:
```
level=info msg="Running main config from specified file" path=/benthos.yaml
level=info msg="Consuming from file './data/dump.txt'" label="" path=root.input
level=trace msg="Consumed 1 messages from 'file'." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Launching a benthos instance, use CTRL+C to close"
level=trace msg="Consumed 1 messages from 'file'." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Listening for HTTP requests at: http://0.0.0.0:4195"
level=trace msg="New group formed: 2022-11-21T09:56:21Z" label="" path=root.pipeline.processors.0
level=trace msg="Attempting to write 1 messages to 'stdout'." label=output path=root.output
level=trace msg="Successfully wrote 1 messages to 'stdout'." label=output path=root.output
level=debug msg="Waiting for pending acks to resolve before shutting down." label="" path=root.input
level=debug msg="Pending acks resolved." label="" path=root.input
level=info msg="Pipeline has terminated. Shutting down the service"
{"events_count":2,"first_event_time":"2022-11-21T08:26:47.872179604Z","window_closed_at":"2022-11-21T09:56:21Z"}

Process finished with exit code 0
```

comment.body: @rolandtritsch I don't really know what people might expect from a generic `event_window` buffer and I'd rather defer to Ash for a potential implementation that is worth pushing into the Benthos codebase, but I could try to help you implement what you're looking to have as a custom plugin, similar to the example here: https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/benthosdev/benthos/v4@v4.10.0/public/service#example-package-BufferPlugin Guess some of the logic from the [`system_window` buffer](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/3f055f41f6494f1feeaec435614f36a8e4375652/internal/impl/pure/buffer_system_window.go) can be reused. We can chat about it on Discord if you'd like. Feel free to DM me.

issue.title: Reading a avro file and decode the go native types
issue.body: @karrick can you please help me with any links or example where they are reading from avro file and then parsing it to Go native types, using either codec.NativeFromTextual or codec.NativeFromBinary APIs. Im struggling a bit for this.

comment.body: Both `NativeFromTextual` and `NativeFromBinary` produce a "native" object that I think is only meant to be used by the Goavro APIs. What you can do is to then call `TextualFromNative` to obtain a JSON string representation and then use `json.Unmarshal` to decode that into a Go structure. Alternatively, I can imagine using something like [mapstructure](https://github.com/mitchellh/mapstructure) to extract what you need from the "native" object, but I'm not sure if that's such a good idea...

issue.title: Sort Output
issue.body:
Hello, 

I have a CSV file.

I try to process each line to add a new field, then, i want to output the line sorted in a new csv file. 
I don't understand how can i sort my output 

For example, with this input csv: 

```csv
first_name;last_name
Bruce;Banner
Tony;Stark
Bruce;Wayne
Barry;Allen
Jason;Todd
Dick;Grayson
```
I want to output this csv : 

```csv
first_name;last_name;full_name
Barry;Allen;Bruce Wayne
Bruce;Banner;Dick Grayson
Bruce;Wayne;Barry Allen
Dick;Grayson;Bruce Banner
Jason;Todd;Tony Stark
Tony;Stark;Jason Todd
```

Currently, i have this config

```yaml
input:
  csv:
    paths: [./benthos.csv]
    delimiter: ";"
    parse_header_row: true

pipeline:
  processors:
    - bloblang: |
        root = this
        root.full_name = this.first_name + " " + this.last_name      
        
output:
  file:
    path: ./benthos_output.csv
```    

But don't understand how i can sort the full batch of line, and not something inside each line

comment.body:
Hey @Varkal, Benthos is a data streaming processor, meaning that it's not really intended for use cases where the entire input data needs to end up in a certain order. Having said that, there are workarounds with various caveats, such as this one:

```yaml
input:
  csv:
    paths: [./benthos.csv]
    delimiter: ";"
    parse_header_row: true

buffer:
  memory:
    limit: 1048576 # 100MB - Something larger than the total size of your input data
    batch_policy:
      enabled: true
      count: 1000000 # 1 million - Something larger than the total number of rows you can possibly have in your input

pipeline:
  processors:
    - archive:
        format: json_array
    - mapping: |
        map escape_csv {
          root = if this.re_match("[\"\n,]+") {
            "\"" + this.replace_all("\"", "\"\"") + "\""
          } else {
            this
          }
        }

        let rows = this.sort_by(i -> i.first_name).map_each(i -> i.merge({"full_name": i.first_name + " " + i.last_name}))
        let cols = $rows.index(0).keys().sort() # Sort here to ensure the order of the columns in the output is deterministic
        let header = $cols.map_each(kv -> kv.apply("escape_csv")).join(",") + "\n"

        root = $header + $rows.map_each(row -> $cols.map_each(c -> row.get(c).string().apply("escape_csv")).join(",")).join("\n")

output:
  file:
    path: ./benthos_output.csv
```

Caveats:
- We must force Benthos to read all the input data in memory. Since you need a custom delimiter, we can't just use the `file` input with `codec: all-bytes` because the [`unarchive` processor](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/unarchive) doesn't support custom delimiters when specifying `format: csv` and the [`parse_csv` bloblang method](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/methods#parse_csv) has the same limitation right now, but I'll send a PR soon to extend the latter. Until then, using a large enough in-memory buffer will do the trick. Alternatively, parsing the CSV manually using various string functions in bloblang is possible, but I'd rather not go down that route... If needed, you could write your own [custom plugin](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos-plugin-example).
- The in-memory buffer batches all the rows (messages) into a batch which we need to collapse into a single message using the `archive` processor, so we can then use the [`sort_by` bloblang method](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/methods#sort_by).
- Since JSON objects don't have any column order, then we must manually sort the columns too if we want the final output CSV to be deterministic. Currently, the `csv` input doesn't store the original column order anywhere, so that information is lost. If it's mandatory to preserve the column order from the input, I have that code almost ready.
- There's no `format_csv` bloblang method / processor or `csv` output yet because it's a bit unclear how to make it generic, but, as explained [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/advanced#creating-csv) there are some workarounds. The mapping I created above is one way, but definitely not the most efficient possible.

Having said that, there are other tools out there which might be more suitable for achieving your goal, such as [xsv](https://github.com/BurntSushi/xsv), [miller](https://github.com/johnkerl/miller), [q](http://github.com/harelba/q), etc.

issue.title: Redaction via struct tags
issue.body:
Would you consider enabling redaction via struct tags? Ideally, I'd like to use it in combination with https://github.com/caarlos0/env like so:
```go
type Config struct {
	Username string `env:"USERNAME" envDefault:"mihai"`
	Password  string `env:"PASSWORD,required" rubberneck:"redact"`
}
```
Maybe the `rubberneck:"redact"` can be even more versatile, to allow users to specify the redaction symbol for example.

For prior art, I found https://github.com/leebenson/conform and I can get it to do redaction through a one liner like so:
```go
conform.AddSanitizer("redact", func(s string) string { return strings.Repeat("*", len(s)) })
```

But it would be so much nicer to have an all-in-one solution :)

issue.body:
# Summary of Changes

This adds the required config for VS Code [Dev Container](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/devcontainers/containers) support. With this change, opening the repo in VS Code will prompt you to reload the editor and, assuming you have Docker up and running, it will pull the required Docker image and start it. Expect it to download a 1.4GB image. Once the container is running, it will install a bunch of dependencies, including `tox`. It will show you the log as it progresses, but, at the end of the process, VS Code will run in this container in headless mode and you can open a separate terminal in which you can run the `tox` command which should complete successfully.

I haven't spotted any specific section related to the code editor in the Readme / Contributing docs, so not sure if you'd like to have a paragraph about this feature, or at least mention somewhere that people will want to use VS Code if they wish to leverage this Dev Container setup for their work / tests.

# Related Issues

Fixes #1979.

# Pull Request Checklist

This is just a reminder about the most common mistakes.  Please make sure that you tick all *appropriate* boxes.  But please read our [contribution guide](../CONTRIBUTING.md) at least once; it will save you a few review cycles!

If an item doesn't apply to your pull request, **check it anyway** to make it apparent that there's nothing to do.

- [ ] Applied changes to both WSGI and ASGI code paths and interfaces (where applicable).
- [ ] Added **tests** for changed code.
- [ ] Prefixed code comments with GitHub nick and an appropriate prefix.
- [ ] Coding style is consistent with the rest of the framework.
- [ ] Updated **documentation** for changed code.
    - [ ] Added docstrings for any new classes, functions, or modules.
    - [ ] Updated docstrings for any modifications to existing code.
    - [ ] Updated both WSGI and ASGI docs (where applicable).
    - [ ] Added references to new classes, functions, or modules to the relevant RST file under `docs/`.
    - [ ] Updated all relevant supporting documentation files under `docs/`.
    - [ ] A copyright notice is included at the top of any new modules (using your own name or the name of your organization).
    - [ ] Changed/added classes/methods/functions have appropriate `versionadded`, `versionchanged`, or `deprecated` [directives](http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/stable/usage/restructuredtext/directives.html?highlight=versionadded#directive-versionadded).
- [ ] Changes (and possible deprecations) have [towncrier](https://towncrier.readthedocs.io/en/latest/quickstart.html#creating-news-fragments) news fragments under `docs/_newsfragments/`, with the file name format `{issue_number}.{fragment_type}.rst`. (Run `towncrier --draft` to ensure it renders correctly.)

If you have *any* questions to *any* of the points above, just **submit and ask**! This checklist is here to *help* you, not to deter you from contributing!

issue.body: I'd like to suggest adding support for Salesforce Object Query Language (SOQL)  as an input/output. I'm willing to take a stab at implementing this if I get the spare time to do it.

comment.body:
No, it doesn't require a sequence input and you can leverage the `memory` cache `default_ttl` to expire tokens. Here's how I'd do it:

```yaml
input:
  generate:
    interval: 10s # Trigger the pipeline every 10s
    mapping: root = ""
    count: 0 # Never stop

  processors:
    - cache: # Try to fetch the auth token from the cache
        resource: token_cache
        operator: get
        key: token
    - catch:
        - http: {} # Fetch the auth token from the API
        - catch:
            - log:
                level: WARN
                message: "Failed to get token: ${! error() }"
            - bloblang: root = deleted() # Prevent the rest of the pipeline from running
        - mapping: |
            meta token = ... # Do some processing to extract the actual token and place it in
        - branch:
            request_map: |
              root = meta("token")
            processors:
              - cache: # Cache the current auth token
                  resource: token_cache
                  operator: set
                  key: token
                  value: "${! content() }"
    - http: {} # Fetch some data using meta("token")

output:
  stdout: {}

cache_resources:
  - label: token_cache
    memory:
      ttl: 1h # Expire auth tokens after 1h
```

Note that the above is just a sketch config and it might have bugs...

issue.title: OUTPUT - Multi SQL insert from args_mapping

labels.name: needs investigation
labels.description: It looks as though have all the information needed but investigation is required

issue.body:
Right now the [SQL insert](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/sql_insert) output only supports 1 item. I would like to have an option that will accept an array of items from the `args_mapping` that can than be expanded in the following manner.

```sql
INSERT INTO table(a, b, c) VALUES (j, k, l), (x, y, z);
```

This way it will be done in 1 statement instead of multiple INSERTS.

comment.body:
Sure! I guess you can start with something like this:

```yaml
input:
  generate:
    mapping: |
      root.type = if count("type") % 3 == 1 { "order" } else { "item" }
      root.id = uuid_v4()
    count: 9
    interval: 0s
    batch_size: 3
  processors:
    - archive:
        format: json_array
    - mapping: |
        root.order = this.filter(item -> item.type == "order").index(0)
        root.items = this.filter(item -> item.type == "item")

output:
  sql_raw:
    driver: sqlite
    dsn: file:./foobar.db
    query: |
      BEGIN TRANSACTION;
      INSERT INTO orders (id) VALUES (?);
      INSERT INTO order_items (id, order_id) VALUES ${! json("items").map_each(i -> "(?, ?)").join(",") };
      COMMIT;
    unsafe_dynamic_query: true
    args_mapping: |
      root = [ this.order.id ].append(this.items.map_each(i -> [this.order.id, i.id]).flatten()).flatten()
    conn_max_idle: 1
    conn_max_open: 1
    init_statement: |
      CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS orders (
        id varchar
      );
      CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS order_items (
        id varchar,
        order_id varchar
      );
```

I'm making some possibly undesired assumptions in there:
- Each batch contains exactly one order and multiple items which have to be inserted in one single transaction
- An order is inserted together with its items in a single transaction
- There's just a single column in each of the two tables called `id`, but you can change that by adjusting the `query` and `args_mapping` fields

> How should a package be emitting logs in a way that makes it ok to use in Benthos?

Have a look at any of the existing implementations under `internal/impl`. For example [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/b0f68e94d7e4e42a7a929b1e493f0fe3e6d84c88/internal/impl/snowflake/output_snowflake_put.go#L734). You can see how that `logger` object is hooked up.

issue.title: how to Preserving key order by json parse  ?

comment.body:
Key order is undefined in JSON and, because Go uses maps to hold JSON objects, the order will not be preserved. Details here: https://github.com/golang/go/issues/27179. When marshalling to string, the keys will be [sorted lexicographically](https://pkg.go.dev/encoding/json):

> Map values encode as JSON objects. The map's key type must either be a string, an integer type, or implement encoding.TextMarshaler. The map keys are sorted and used as JSON object keys by applying the following rules, subject to the UTF-8 coercion described for string values above:
> 
>     keys of any string type are used directly
>     encoding.TextMarshalers are marshaled
>     integer keys are converted to strings

issue.title: base64_decode execution error
issue.body:
There is an error using base64_decode in awk processor.
the error info is:
```
level=error msg="Non-fatal execution error: illegal base64 data at input byte 43220" @service=benthos label="" path=root.pipeline.processors.2
```
my benthos.config:
```yaml
input:
  broker:
    inputs:
      - kafka:
          addresses: kafka_addrss
          topics: kafka_topic
          consumer_group: kafka_group
          sasl:
            mechanism: kafka_me
            user: kafka_user
            password: kafka_password
pipeline:
  processors:
    - protobuf:
        operator: to_json
        message: subscribe.Envelope
        import_paths: [ subscribe/subscribe.proto ]
    - awk:
        codec: "json"
        program: |
          function readfile(file, tmp, save_rs){
            save_rs = RS
            RS = "^$"
            getline tmp < file
            close(file)
            RS = save_rs

            return tmp
          }
          {
            total_value = json_get("total")
            index_type = json_type("index")
            if (index_type == "undefined") {
              json_set_int("index",0)
            }
            index_value = json_get("index")
            data_value = json_get("data")
            if (index_value == "0") {
              print data_value > "./result.json"
            } else {
              file_data = readfile("./result.json")
              gsub(/\s/,"",file_data)
              file_data = sprintf("%s%s",file_data,data_value)
              print data_value > "./result.json"
              }
            }
    - awk: 
        codec: "json"
        program: |
          function readfile(file, tmp, save_rs){
            save_rs = RS
            RS = "^$"
            getline tmp < file
            close(file)
            RS = save_rs

            return tmp
          }
          {
            data_com = readfile("./result.json")
            gsub(/\s/,"",data_com)
            decode_data = base64_decode(data_com)
            json_set("data",decode_data)
          }
    - catch: 
        - resource: error_data
    - bloblang: |
        root = this.data
    - protobuf:
        operator: to_json
        message: subscribe.Entries
        import_paths: [subscribe/subscribe.proto]
          
processor_resources:
  - label: error_data
    awk:
      codec: "json"
      program: |
        function readfile(file, tmp, save_rs){
          save_rs = RS
          RS = "^$"
          getline tmp < file
          close(file)
          RS = save_rs
          return tmp
        }
        {
          data_com = readfile("./result.json")
          gsub(/\s/,"",data_com)
          print data_com > "./err_data.json"
        }
output: 
  drop: {}
```
Why does decoding fail? My data is processed from protobuf processor.

comment.body:
> Why does decoding fail? My data is processed from protobuf processor.

I see many operations in there before it even reaches `base64_decode`. It's really hard to tell if, indeed, that `result.json` file contains a valid base64-encoded string. To narrow it down, I suggest you insert a `log` processor between the `protobuf` one and the first `awk` one and then, after you capture one of those messages, replace your input with a `generate` input which simply produces the data from the JSON you captured. That way, you'll have an easily-reproducible example to play with and share with us if you still need help.

Additionally, it seems to me like a lot of the logic which is done via `awk`, if not all of it, would be way more maintainable if expressed via bloblang using `mapping` processors. Have you found some limitations in bloblang which prevent you from using it? Also, storing state to disk in those json files via `awk` makes things way more difficult than they should be. Have you considered using a [cache](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/caches/about) instead? Also, if it's something related to the current message, [metadata](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/configuration/metadata/) is getting [support](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/issues/1558) for structured data in the next release, which can simplify things a lot.

Another thing to keep in mind is that if any of the processors fails, you can inspect the error in a `log` processor using `message: ${! error() }`. The `error()` function is documented [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/functions#error).

Hi,

meta("path").filepath_split().index(1).has_suffix("csv") 
But this logic gets evaluated per file record count. Is it possible it run the processor per file only once.
Reference code snippet below.
input:
  broker:
    inputs:
      - resource: in_files
pipeline:
  threads: 1
  processors:
     - try:
        - resource: resource_1
        - resource: resource_2  
        - log:
             level: INFO
             message: execution start  
     - catch:
       - log:
          level: ERROR
          message: "Failed due to: ${! error() }"
       - resource: resource_3
output:
  switch:
    cases:
      - check: this.status=="ERROR"
        output:
          label: error

            - resource: resource_4

            codec: lines

processor_resources:

            if (!this.filename.has_suffix("csv")  ){
               throw("File Extention is invalid")
            }
        - label: resource_3
          bloblang: |
              root.status = "ERROR"
              root.filename = meta("path").filepath_split().index(1)
              root.reason = "%s%v".format("Failed due to: ",error())
        - label: resource_4
          bloblang: |
            "FILE : %s\rREASON : %s \r\r".format(this.filename, this.reason)                    

input_resources:
  - label: in_files
    file:
      paths:
        - /input/*.*

comment.body: Hey @dhaldergit, it sounds like you'd want the `file` input to only emit one message for each file read containing only the metadata of the files. I guess we could add something like a `metadata` codec, but it will require a bit of investigation.

pull_request.title: Add format_xml bloblang method
pull_request.body:
Also add `no_indent` parameter to the `format_json()` bloblang method. Unfortunately, we can't currently distinguish between `format_json()` and `format_json("    ")`, so the easiest thing to do is to add an extra parameter to be consistent with `format_xml()`. Otherwise, people can't force these methods to not insert any `\n` characters, because setting the indent to `""` still emits them and, then again, diverging from the Go API behaviour is probably a bad idea...

Unfortunately, I couldn't use `encoding/xml` for this task because it has some limitations such as https://github.com/golang/go/issues/48624. It's not clear to me why it doesn't support the same kinds of inputs as `encoding/json`, but, alas...

issue.title: Would you consider maintaining a devcontainer for VS Code?
issue.body:
I struggled a bit to get `tools/mintest.sh` to run and since I'm not a very experienced Python developer, setting up the prerequisites on OSX proved to be a challenge. Having multiple versions of Python in parallel seems a bit error-prone to me. I guess using `pyenv` from the start is the way to go, but wasn't sure based on the instructions from [here](https://github.com/falconry/falcon/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md). On the other hand, I recently played around with a project called Keda and I found [their devcontainer setup](https://github.com/kedacore/keda/tree/main/.devcontainer) quite easy to use, assuming one is willing to run Docker. Basically, VS Code starts a headless server in the container automatically and then the UI communicates with it seamlessly.

For Falcon, I found it easier to install all the dependencies in a Docker container and run everything there without worrying about messing up Python on my local laptop:
```shell
> docker run --rm -it -v$(pwd):/workspace ubuntu bash
>> apt update && DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive apt install -y software-properties-common ca-certificates curl build-essential python3-distutils python3-pip
>> add-apt-repository -y ppa:deadsnakes/ppa && apt update
>> apt install -y python3.5 python3.8 python3.5-dev python3.8-dev
>> pip install -U pip setuptools tox wheel
>> cd /workspace
>> # Run mintest
>> tools/mintest.sh
>> # Run asgilook test
>> tox --recreate -e asgilook
>> # Run asgilook tests without refreshing dependencies
>> tox --skip-pkg-install -e asgilook
```

I can easily wrap the above in a devcontainer if you'd like.

# Summary of Changes

This adds the required config for VS Code [Dev Container](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/devcontainers/containers) support. With this change, opening the repo in VS Code will prompt you to reload the editor and, assuming you have Docker up and running, it will pull the required Docker image and start it. Expect it to download a 1.4GB image. Once the container is running, it will install a bunch of dependencies, including `tox`. It will show you the log as it progresses, but, at the end of the process, VS Code will run in this container in headless mode and you can open a separate terminal in which you can run the `tox` command which should complete successfully.

I haven't spotted any specific section related to the code editor in the Readme / Contributing docs, so not sure if you'd like to have a paragraph about this feature, or at least mention somewhere that people will want to use VS Code if they wish to leverage this Dev Container setup for their work / tests.

# Related Issues

Fixes #1979.

# Pull Request Checklist

This is just a reminder about the most common mistakes.  Please make sure that you tick all *appropriate* boxes.  But please read our [contribution guide](../CONTRIBUTING.md) at least once; it will save you a few review cycles!

If an item doesn't apply to your pull request, **check it anyway** to make it apparent that there's nothing to do.

- [ ] Applied changes to both WSGI and ASGI code paths and interfaces (where applicable).
- [ ] Added **tests** for changed code.
- [ ] Prefixed code comments with GitHub nick and an appropriate prefix.
- [ ] Coding style is consistent with the rest of the framework.
- [ ] Updated **documentation** for changed code.
    - [ ] Added docstrings for any new classes, functions, or modules.
    - [ ] Updated docstrings for any modifications to existing code.
    - [ ] Updated both WSGI and ASGI docs (where applicable).
    - [ ] Added references to new classes, functions, or modules to the relevant RST file under `docs/`.
    - [ ] Updated all relevant supporting documentation files under `docs/`.
    - [ ] A copyright notice is included at the top of any new modules (using your own name or the name of your organization).
    - [ ] Changed/added classes/methods/functions have appropriate `versionadded`, `versionchanged`, or `deprecated` [directives](http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/stable/usage/restructuredtext/directives.html?highlight=versionadded#directive-versionadded).
- [ ] Changes (and possible deprecations) have [towncrier](https://towncrier.readthedocs.io/en/latest/quickstart.html#creating-news-fragments) news fragments under `docs/_newsfragments/`, with the file name format `{issue_number}.{fragment_type}.rst`. (Run `towncrier --draft` to ensure it renders correctly.)

If you have *any* questions to *any* of the points above, just **submit and ask**! This checklist is here to *help* you, not to deter you from contributing!

issue.title: Importing puslar client libraries creates zombie dbus processes

labels.name: annoying
labels.description: Benthos is mildly annoying but not quite a bug

labels.name: waiting for upstream
labels.description: Blocked on changes needed in an upstream dependency

issue.body:
As per discord chat with @Jeffail and @mihaitodor:

Running any of benthos subcommands in a cronjob will create
`/usr/bin/dbus-daemon --session` processes for every invocation, slowing down
the system or ultimately crashing it.

This is most likely because there are no dbus sessions available to cron processes.

Way to reproduce:

```
# cat /etc/cron.d/foo
* * * * * root benthos --version
# Wait a few minutes
# ps aux | grep dbus
message+     605  0.0  0.0   8572  4460 ?        Ss   11:28   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --system --address=systemd: --nofork --nopidfile --systemd-activation --syslog-o
root      302826  0.0  0.0   8268  2480 ?        Ss   19:16   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      303318  0.0  0.0   8268  2480 ?        Ss   19:17   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      303870  0.0  0.0   8268  2504 ?        Ss   19:18   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
... a few more ...
root      309243  0.0  0.0   8268  2480 ?        Ss   19:28   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      309737  0.0  0.0   8268  2540 ?        Ss   19:29   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      310353  0.0  0.0   8268  2484 ?        Ss   19:30   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
root      310842  0.0  0.0   8268  2484 ?        Ss   19:31   0:00 /usr/bin/dbus-daemon --syslog --fork --print-pid 4 --print-address 6 --session
```

This also happens on every invocation in a regular shell on a system where dbus
is disabled / not existent (e.g. OpenRC systems).

The root cause is most likely this:
https://github.com/99designs/keyring/blob/81fed19d324843057dab56ba67dd0db54d1d4626/secretservice.go#L19

Workaround is to set `DBUS_SESSION_BUS_ADDRESS=/dev/null` as environment
variable in the cron file or from where ever else you might run it.

issue.title: Output subprocess dynamic
issue.body:
Hello all,
I try to use subprocess output but i don't know if it's the best way for implement my use case.

My config.yml

```
input:
  label: ""
  kafka:
    addresses: ["ip:29092"]
    topics: ["topic"]
    target_version: 2.0.0
    consumer_group: "group_name"
    checkpoint_limit: 1024
    
- mapping: |
        root.param1 = this.id

output:
  broker:
    outputs:
    - subprocess:
        name: "node"
        args: ["run"]
        codec: lines
```

I want to run dynamic command like 

`node run {"param1": "value1"}`

where the value of the hash key "param1" is the result of a mapping processor 'root.param1'

comment.body:
Hey @malveslobo, the `subprocess` output doesn't work this way, as it's meant to start a long-running process which keeps reading data from stdin. See the docs [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/subprocess). If you're using node anyway, the easiest and more reliable thing to do might be to add a small HTTP server into your node app and then use the `http_client` output in Benthos. Having said that, you can try a quick and dirty workaround using bash:

```shell
#!/bin/bash

while read -r line
do
    node run "${line}"
done
```

Put this script in a file, do `subprocess.name: wrapper.sh` and leave the `args` empty (unless you also want to make it more complex and pass some args to it).

issue.title: Add service.AutoRetryNacks test for read after close
issue.body:
I believe this test should succeed, but I could be wrong... 

I'm trying to fix this other test https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/main/internal/impl/mongodb/input_test.go and it looks like there's smth wonky with the way `public/service/input_auto_retry.go` works. Basically, I'm expecting `selectInput.Read(ctx)` here https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/b195d9eb87f6b4a5637330f4e276b06ea344ff17/internal/impl/mongodb/input_test.go#L235 to unblock when `service.ErrEndOfInput` is returned by the input `Read()` method, but that doesn't seem to be the case. Right now, it's just blocking forever, because the test author of the test didn't use `context.WithTimeout()`, but that's another issue... There are a few other issues in this MongoDB test that I'll address once this issue is clarified.

comment.body: OK, it should be good to go now. I think it's a useful test to have there in case I need to review this logic again in the future.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -339,3 +339,51 @@ func TestAutoRetryBuffer(t *testing.T) {
 	require.NoError(t, err)
 	assert.Equal(t, exp3, string(b))
 }
+
+func TestAutoRetryReadAfterClose(t *testing.T) {
+	t.Parallel()
+
+	ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), time.Second*2)
+	defer cancel()
+
+	readerImpl := newMockInput()
+	readerImpl.msgsToSnd = append(readerImpl.msgsToSnd, NewMessage([]byte("foo")))
+
+	pres := AutoRetryNacks(readerImpl)
+
+	wg := sync.WaitGroup{}
+	wg.Add(1)
+	go func() {
+		defer wg.Done()
+		select {
+		case readerImpl.connChan <- nil:
+		case <-time.After(time.Second):
+			t.Error("Timed out")
+		}
+		select {
+		case readerImpl.readChan <- nil:
+		case <-time.After(time.Second):
+			t.Error("Timed out")
+		}
+
+		// Force mockInput.Read() to return ErrEndOfInput
+		close(readerImpl.readChan)
+	}()
+
+	require.NoError(t, pres.Connect(ctx))
+
+	msg, _, err := pres.Read(ctx)
comment.body: Ahhhhh! That makes sense. I forgot about the ack function... Indeed, it has to be called to unblock the workflow. Thanks a million! 😘
